title: Tuesday, 28th June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

It's still a bloody mess, even if markets have steadied

PM

The football, sheesh

11:02 am
PM

Here's something to perk everyone up

PM

PM

Dont click that

11:02 am
PM

Click this

PM
PM

Sandra Rupp does Brexit analysis

11:03 am
PM

She has an audience in 65 countries now

PM

Which is possibly more than ours

BE

(Let the transcript record that I don't need any cheering up.)

11:04 am

Sandra's video camera seems to be broken

PM

She's just used stills on this occasion

PM

Or maybe she just wasnt prepared for camera, but felt she needed to get her Brexit analysis out there

11:05 am

But didnt have the right dress

PM

Cos how do you dress for such an event?

PM

It's a tough question

11:05 am

We've also been getting loads of enquiries about the dress code for Camp AV on friday

BE

(@Flaneur: hopefully.)

PM

11:06 am
PM

People, he?

PM

Wear clothes ok?

BE

There's a slideshow on the promo page: http://ftalphavill...s-london-hac-july/

11:07 am
BE

Take your cues from that.

PM

Any way I think it's sold out now

PM

So don't bother clicking this link: https://live.ft.co...estival-of-Finance

11:07 am
PM

One thing we can thank Brexit for

PM

We've only had one speaker cancellation -- and even that's not confirmed

PM

And we've had a queue of other people wanting a platform

11:08 am
PM

But the schedule's full. So stop pestering us.

PM

You had your chance

PM

Anyway, that's friday

11:08 am
PM

Today is today

BE

This is a lot of intro for a conference you can neither speak at nor get a ticket for.

BE

We should really turn to current events.

11:09 am
PM

Yeah

PM

BE

?

11:09 am
PM

aww

PM

It's a dead cat Bryce

BE

Ah.

11:09 am
PM

We're borrowing more stuff from Buzzfeed

PM

Simon Neville @SimonNeville
Nice to see the FT using BuzzFeed's name to try and drive it's own traffic and flog tickets... You're welcome?

PM

omg smile

11:10 am
undefined
BE

Don't start that. There's really not much more dull to a general audience than media pulling each others' tails.

BE

So. We're rallying. FTSE 100 up 2.4% at pixel.

11:11 am
BE

142 points.

BE

But it's been a pretty messy couple of days, and the rally has to be seen in that context.

BE

By my figures, 656 LSE stocks have hit one-year lows since Friday morning.

11:12 am
BE

Including about half the FTSE 100.

PM

(......

PM

UK Business Editor
BuzzFeed
March 2016 – Present (4 months)London, United Kingdom
Retail Correspondent
Evening Standard
September 2013 – March 2016 (2 years 7 months)London
Business reporter
Guardian Group
May 2012 – September 2013 (1 year 5 months)London, United Kingdom
Showbiz reporter
Daily Mail

News Reporter

Online Reporter

City Reporter
Daily Mail

11:12 am
PM

....)

PM

(sorry. will stop)

BE

...... But also, about a quarter of the FTSE 100 has hit 52-week highs.

11:13 am
BE

Is there some kind of reverse Hindenburg Omen?

PM

Extraordinary

BE

The ratio is 2.2 highs to lows as predicting a crash, I think.

11:14 am
BE

I guess the flip is 2.2 lows to highs predicting a dead cat.

BE

Maybe. I'm open to the theory, having just made it up.

PM

Very good Bryce

11:15 am
PM

Should we name this

PM

??

PM

The Elder Reverse

11:15 am
BE

Nah -- needs to follow the giant catastrophe theme.

BE

The Tay Rail Bridge Harbinger.

PM

™

11:16 am
BE

The Joe Hart Bodement.

BE

Something like that.

BE

Anyway. Insurers leading us up today.

11:17 am
Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,227, up 121.5 (+11.00%), High: 1,227, Low: 1,133, Volume: 4.72m
Legal & General Group PLC (LGEN:LSE): Last: 180.00, up 15 (+9.09%), High: 181.70, Low: 173.10, Volume: 20.05m
Aviva PLC (AV.:LSE): Last: 372.70, up 26.5 (+7.65%), High: 373.43, Low: 359.60, Volume: 7.30m
11:17 am
Old Mutual PLC (OML:LSE): Last: 186.50, up 8.4 (+4.72%), High: 187.10, Low: 182.50, Volume: 5.23m
BE

(Which isn't really a proper insurer, but it isn't really a proper anything else either.)

BE

There's a lot of stuff around saying "solvency fine, chill out everyone"

11:18 am
BE

For a change, here's Autonomous.

BE

 Brexit wreckage: Against the backdrop of anaemic GDP growth globally,
investment markets are acutely susceptible to exogenous shocks. Following
China worries last August and oil/ credit concerns in January- February, this is
the third strike, cascading the market from faltering rallies to ever lower levels.
Insurers, with invested assets 5.4x the size of their tangible equity, are bound
to sit in investors’ cross hairs – unsurprisingly they have fallen sharply.

BE

 Low rate replay: With each set-back, core bond yields fall (for) ever lower.
Central bankers may be running out of ammo but their policy response, ever
more expansive bond buying programmes, underwrites low credit defaults.

11:19 am
BE

This is Andrew Crean, by the way. Ex of Citi.

BE

 Insurance - UK vs continental Europe: Low rates, here to stay, are a particular
problem in continental Europe – not just in Germany & the Netherlands but
more widely as AXA made clear last week. For UK life companies, credit is the
issue. Thus they are more beneficiaries than victims of prevailing policy. Brexit
increases recessionary risks although a weaker currency may offset. Without a
default spike, UK insurers are set fair.

BE

 Risk off in vogue: P/C names (primary & reinsurance) with their lower asset
gearing, have outperformed the broader equity market during the current
debacle (-3% since 14th June). Brexit does not make their businesses any more
attractive than before so why rush in now – there must be safer safe havens?

11:20 am
BE

 Risk on – too scary? Given substantial recent share price falls, theoretically the
more highly geared life/ multi-liner names offer better value. We have run S-II
screens and find most post coverage ratios above their ‘lower bounds’ even
under further market stress. Given yields up to & above 8%, we are tempted
but would wait for macro sentiment to improve.

BE

 Asset gathering names: We are lowering sector earnings by just -2%, in
marked contrast to the banks. Only for asset gathering names do forecasts fall
by double-digit percentages, now reflected in similar stock price falls. We
upgrade Standard Life (OP) on this theme given lower residual B/S concerns.

BE

 Other rating changes: We lower Delta Lloyd to UP given outsize capital
concerns. Swiss Re comes back to N given balance sheet resilience.

11:21 am
BE

Let me add a couple of charts. Autonomous stuff is exceptionally good, but we need to take care not to annoy their copyright people too much.

BE

Solvency risks:

BE

11:23 am
BE

And S2 stress testing.

BE

undefined
11:24 am
BE

Elsewhere in world of deadcat

BE

Housebuilders -- which were my nap to bounce strongest, when the bounce came -- aren't really.

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 121.60, up 5.8 (+5.01%), High: 126.10, Low: 116.40, Volume: 33.75m
11:25 am
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 367.60, up 13.2 (+3.72%), High: 382.50, Low: 354.20, Volume: 4.90m
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 2,352, up 11 (+0.47%), High: 2,635, Low: 2,279, Volume: 1.18m
BE

Look at Berkeley! Cripes.

11:26 am
BE

If you believe housebuilders will go into crisis mode and just flog the houses they're building, rather than replenishing land banks, these look relatively safe 10%-ish divi yields down here.

BE

I should note, though, that Goldman doesn't fancy the sector.

BE

GS's Brexit construction downgrades dropped in this morning, for the robots that read Goldman research.

11:28 am
BE

Following the UK’s EU referendum, our economists have lowered their
2017 UK GDP growth forecast by 1.8 pp to 0.2% yoy and their Euro area
forecast by 0.3 pp to 1.2% yoy. Our European Construction forecasts for
2016/17 therefore fall 1.5 pp/1.9 pp respectively to +1.1%/+0.8%, mainly
driven by lowered UK forecasts. For UK housing, we now expect new build
volumes to fall 10% in 2017 (+7% previously) and UK house prices to fall by
2%/5% in 2016/17E.

BE

Following the reduction in our Construction market forecasts, our EBITDA
forecasts are lowered by medians of 4%/12% for 2016/17, respectively. Our
UK Housing subsector sees the greatest reductions (2017E median EBITDA
reduction of 42%), followed by Merchants (-16%) and Building Materials (-
8%). Contractors as a group see the least impact (-0.3%) on account of less
average exposure to UK/European markets and less exposure to more
cyclical building construction.

BE

We reflect the heightened level of market uncertainty in our target
multiples and apply a 10% discount for UK exposure and a 5% discount for
European and weight this based on sales exposure for our stocks.

11:29 am
BE

We make 10 rating changes. We upgrade LafargeHolcim and Wolseley to
Buy (from Neutral); we downgrade Braas Monier, Bovis, Redrow, Crest
Nicholson (off CL) and Bellway to Neutral from Buy. We downgrade
Berkeley Group, Countrywide and Foxtons to Sell from Neutral. We also
remove the Not Rated designation from Salini Impregilo and reinstate as
Neutral.

BE

Cracking timing with that Foxtons downgrade. Day after a profit warning.

BE

We have removed Crest and Wienerberger from our CL as we lower our
estimates and valuation. We believe Wienerberger lacks catalysts as we
now think a residential construction recovery in Europe has been delayed
by 18-24 months. But the stock remains attractively valued and we see
sufficient upside - Buy. HeidelbergCement (CL Buy) remains our top pick.

11:30 am
PM

Rabble are picking up on this 2/5% drop line

PM

Maybe it was a typo

PM

- instead of no space

11:31 am
PM

I'm joking, just to be clear

PM

Welcome to ML

PM

Amongst smug owners of houses in places like Greenwich

11:32 am
BE

Look, it's Goldman sellside. It's like reading treacle. Let me find the bit that explains what they're talking about re house prices.

BE

While the outlook for the housing market remains highly uncertain following the
referendum vote last week, we have incorporated reductions to our market growth
assumptions to reflect the latest lead indicators and our views of: 1) a weaker macro
backdrop, 2) heightened uncertainty linked to the labour and lending market, and 3)
pressures in the Buy-to-Let market from the recent policy changes. These factors result in
our forecasts for UK transactions reducing to -10%/-11% for 2016/17 (from 1%2%). We
also reduce our newbuild completions forecasts to 1%-10% (from 7%/7%). Our forecasts
continue to show newbuild outpacing the secondary transactions market, reflecting the
undersupplied nature of the market and the policy support that we expect will drive
newbuild over the medium term. In terms of pricing, we lower our 2016/17 house price
inflation forecasts to -2%/-5% for the UK (3%3% earlier) and -4%-8% for London (from
3%/2%) reflecting our concerns around stretched affordability in the region. We note that
there could be upside risks to our current estimates from any new policies/schemes
announced by the government to promote stability in the market.

BE

11:33 am
PM

er, thx

BE

Yeah, there we are.

So! What else?

Ocado?

wt...

11:36 am

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 230.00, up 21.9 (+10.52%), High: 240.00, Low: 218.60, Volume: 2.21m
PM

omg smile omg smile omg smile

11:37 am
BE

There's nothing like returning to normality via a waffle about Ocado.

BE

So it seems that Amazon Fresh hasn't had a significant impact on Ocado in the three or four days after its launch.

BE

Therefore, it never will. QED, mate.

11:38 am
PM

(Rabble -- the best ever piece on Johnson is this: https://www.thegua...-be-prime-minister )

BE

.... and the fact that Ocado's earnings are weaker than expected can be ignored.

BE

And the fact that consensus has nudged down -- again! -- is apparently worth 11% on Ocado shares.

11:39 am
BE

Oh, and there's still no partnership news.

BE

It's still a UK-isolated grocer with a surreal cost structure and a 1% market share.

BE

Here's Goldman again.

11:41 am
BE

Ocado reported 1H16 results with retail revenue growth of 13.6% in line
with GSe and 2H15. Within this, volume growth was very strong with
average orders per week +17.8% (FY15 16.8%) and underlying basket
deflation 2.2% (average basket down 3.3% including Fetch.com and Sizzle
orders). Active customers were up 14.9% in the period.
Group EBITDA increased 5.7% to £40.4 mn, c.4% below GSe and c.5.5%
below StreetAccount consensus. The slower profitability growth is driven
by underlying costs increasing as average item prices fall. A part of this
slowdown is also related to Morrisons’ fees being largely fixed.
Cash flow improved in the period, with operating cash flow up 18.7% to
£48.8 mn and free cash flow up to £3.9 mn from £0.5 mn in 1H15. Gross
debt at period-end was £188.9 mn (1H15: £175.5 mn) with cash and cash
equivalents of £52.7 mn (vs £45.8 mn end-FY15).
On CFC3, Ocado says that testing is going well and it expects to go live in
autumn this year. CFC4 is expected to be ready for operations in FY18.
On Ocado Smart Platform, the company states that it is in discussions with
many potential international retailers and it remains confident in its ability
to sign multiple deals in the medium term.

BE

\o/ medium term \o/

BE

Analysis
While market conditions have limited EBITDA growth in the period, the
continued strong growth in order volumes supports the long-term outlook
for the business and underlines the attractiveness of Ocado to customers
despite intense competition. Trading at close to 1x EV/sales and down
c.30% YTD, we think the stock has strong valuation support here.

11:41 am
BE

Implications
Given guidance that basket deflation is expected to continue into 2H16 we
would expect consensus FY16 EBITDA estimates (Reuters £93.3 mn) to fall
by the c.5-6% range by which Ocado missed in 1H16.

BE

And Morgan Stanley.

PM

unbelievable

11:42 am
BE

Bottom line: Overall, despite ongoing deflationary pressures on its top line,
Ocado posted a resilient top and bottom line update. Having spoken to the
company, the tone remains confident on the medium term outlook but it is
worth flagging industry headwinds this year (deflation in the top line and cost
inflation). So all in, despite the robust trading, under the assumption that
analysts anticipate the same level of headwinds in H2, it would mean
consensus could move within the range of £80m to £90m (from ~£94m
today).

PM

Just unbelievable

BE

What's new? Ocado just reported its 1H16 earnings for the 24 weeks to 24
May 2016 this morning. There will be an analyst meeting at 9:30 am UKT
(webcast available on ocadogroup.com).
Top line: Ocado reported Retail sales growth of +14% in Q2, in line with the
trend seen in Q1 despite a comp base 100bps tougher. The decline in the
average basket size increased sequentially but this was offset by the
acceleration in the average orders per week (~19% in Q2 vs. ~17% in Q1
despite a comp base 100bps harder).
Margins: Overall, Group EBITDA reached £40.4m in the first half, up 5.7% YoY.
We do not have an official consensus, but believe this is slightly shy of median
sell-side expectations (closer to £42m we believe). The margin evolution is due
to gross margin pressures (-36bps) being partially offset by efficiency gains
(mostly on Trunking & Delivery). Also, the contribution from Morrison's
operations in terms of fees paid to Ocado grew less than last year.
Cash: Net operating cash flow increased to £49m up ~18% YoY on improving
EBITDA and Working capital generation. However, as Ocado is investing in
expanding its capacity (doubling its existing capacity over the next two years),
its capex spend meant that its cash at period end stood at £52.7m – this is
better than at the year-end (£46m) but due to capex, lower than at the end of
last year's first-half (£70m).
Strategic update: Ocado says its discussions with "many potential
international retailers to adopt the Ocado Smart Platform solution" continue.
Regarding the opening of CFC3, Ocado expects to go live at the site after the
quieter summer period when they can continue to operate from the existing
facilities (thanks to recent efficiency gains there which allow to increase their
initial capacity). CFC4, initially targeted to open towards the end of 2017, is
now planned for 2018 in order to increase the potential eventual capacity
above the initially expected 200k OPW (orders per week).

11:43 am
BE

You're paying an EV of 16 times 2017 EBITDA for this thing.

BE

Assuming you believe the 2017 EBITDA consensus, which would be foolhardy given the number of cuts we've had in its short listed life.

BE

You can buy a normal grocer -- ie, one that makes money -- for about 6 times.

11:44 am
BE

Your choice.

undefined
BE

Okay, where now? I've slightly lost track of comments.

11:45 am
BE

Shawbrook, I guess, needs a mention.

Shawbrook Group PLC (SHAW:LSE): Last: 145.70, down 17.4 (-10.67%), High: 156.00, Low: 117.30, Volume: 7.94m
BE

Challenging the established banks by writing borky loans and failing to put them through the books properly.

11:46 am
BE

CFO's exited.

PM

Hang on, this has only been on the market for how long?

PM

hmm

11:47 am
PM

15 months

BE

Think it was one of the earlier floaters.

PM

Tombstone incoming...

11:48 am
PM

Joint Sponsors, Joint Global Co-ordinators and Joint Bookrunners

BofA Merrill Lynch Goldman Sachs International

Arif Vohra James Fleming Anthony Gutman William Smiley

Matt Blawat Pete Nicholls John Brennan Ken Hayahara

020 7174 4000 020 7774 1000

Joint Bookrunners

Macquarie Capital

Jonny Allison Kavita Choitram Nick Stamp

020 3037 2000

Co-Lead Manager

Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a Stifel Company

Charles Lucas

BE

Anyway, we get a £9m charge in Q2, due to "irregularities" in the group's Asset Finance
business

PM

Rather surprised the fall isn't 40% rather than 10%

11:48 am
BE

Hey look! It's Goldman on the tombstone! We haven't heard enough from Goldman today. What are they saying I wonder?

BE

Analysis
In the release the group also commented that "trading has been in line with
guidance given at the Investor Day" (May 5, 2016), with 2Q16 originations
flat qoq and up c.35% yoy.
For the group as a whole we currently forecast 1H16 impairments of
£5.4 mn (of which Business Finance contributes £1.5 mn), hence today's
trading update will cause a material increase in 1H16E impairments.
Further out, a key concern will be how asset quality across the group's
business develops in what our economists expect to be a worsening
macroeconomic environment.

BE

Implications
We recently downgraded the shares to Neutral owing to slower loan
growth and a weaker credit outlook. We currently expect group
impairments to rise to £21 mn (57 bp) in 2016E and £48 mn in 2017E
(128 bp) due to the weaker credit outlook. We are Neutral-rated on
Shawbrook Group and our 12-month ROTE/COE-based price target is 230p.
Key risks to our view are better/worse than expected loan volume growth,
credit quality and margin developments. Underpinning this, further
significant developments in the UK macroeconomic environment are a key
risk to our view (both to the upside and downside).

11:50 am
BE

We should note that the CFO's exit (his name's Tom Wood, FWIW) is unrelated to the fact that his books were wrong.

BE

And we shouldn't jump to any kind of conclusions about the fact that they haven't lined up a replacement, so are getting the Director of Strategy to be FD in the meantime.

PM

Hang

11:51 am
PM

on

PM

It's a bank

BE

Of sorts, yes.

11:52 am
PM

You can't have irregularities in the book and just continue to be a bank, with the strategy guy as FD

PM

That's not how things work

BE

Nevertheless! Mr Wood's exit is unrelated to the fact that the sums didn't add up.

11:52 am
BE

Just want to clarify that. In case there was any doubt.

BE

This is, of course, post the small banks getting absolutely wiped out over the past couple of days.

BE

Aldermore, Close Brothers, OneSavings, Paragon all down 40% or thereabouts.

11:54 am
BE

Peter Lenardos at RBC talks us through what's happening.

BE

We believe that the share price reaction is a result of uncertainty over:
l Growth/net new lending levels.
l Impairment levels/cost of risk.
l House prices (which if they decline materially could result in higher capital requirements and/or increased impairment levels).
l Lack of seasoning of the loan book (except for Paragon and Close Brothers, which have the most seasoned loan books).
l A potential interest rate cut could also pressure net interest margins, as the specialty lenders (except for Paragon) are largely term deposit funded.

BE

With an uncertain outlook for the sector, we believe that earnings forecasts will be subject to a wide range that will also be absent high levels of conviction. Thus, in our opinion, book values will become increasingly important.

11:55 am
BE

BE

However, return on equity must still be considered. The sector trades at an average price-to-book of 1.09x, with a sector ROE north of 20%. Even if
guidance is no longer applicable (is it too early to tell), we believe that sector valuations look overly draconian, but acknowledge that the uncertain
political, economic and market backdrop will likely weigh on sentiment for the time being. We do note that Paragon recently restarted its share
buyback programme, which given Paragon’s valuation, is both book value and earnings accretive. Paragon has over £14 million of share purchases to
complete under its current authorisation.

Aldermore Group PLC (ALD:LSE): Last: 116.30, up 2.3 (+2.02%), High: 122.10, Low: 114.90, Volume: 1.29m
11:55 am
Close Brothers Group PLC (CBG:LSE): Last: 1,068, up 27 (+2.59%), High: 1,095, Low: 1,061, Volume: 195.37k
OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 178.80, up 2.6 (+1.48%), High: 185.60, Low: 173.20, Volume: 547.64k
Paragon Group of Companies Plc (PAG:LSE): Last: 247.50, up 6.5 (+2.70%), High: 251.00, Low: 243.80, Volume: 708.50k
11:56 am
PM

Just too difficult to value these things at the mo

BE

I'd agree. Still don't really have a handle on how much their books are stuffed with high LTV mortgages on newbuilds and buy-to-lets.

BE

If we get a proper transaction slowdown, the plates could well stop spinning.

11:57 am
undefined
BE

GW requested, repeatedly.

GW Pharmaceuticals PLC (GWP:LSE): Last: 555.00, down 11.5 (-2.03%), High: 579.50, Low: 533.50, Volume: 198.44k
11:58 am
BE

Promising news yesterday on Epidiolex, which seems to have gone through the LGS Phase III without too much trouble.

BE

Plus there was a positive read on the Dravet stuff previously announced.

BE

This is all quite promising. I know we've been cautious about GW in the past, due not least to its tenfold rerating after joining Nasdaq, which might or might not have been on some confusion among CNBC viewers about what it actually does .....

12:00 pm
BE

But the drug seems to work, treating stuff where treatment options are currently close to zero.

BE

Leerink are positive, as always.

BE

• Bottom Line: This morning, GWPH announced positive results for
its 1st Phase 3 study for Epidiolex in Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome
(LGS). We offered a preliminary reaction here (LINK); our view remains
positive after the conference call. Treatment with Epidiolex showed a
22% (44% Epidiolex vs 22% placebo) effect size that was statistically
significant (p=0.0135). GW noted that the second LGS phase III study
will read out in late 3Q16, and mgmt. expects to hold a pre-NDA meeting
on LGS in 2H16. We are raising our PT to $138 from $130 on a higher
probability-of-success in LGS (now 85% from 75%) and a slightly higher
probability of approval in Dravet (90% from 85%). Reit. OP on GWPH.

12:00 pm
BE

• Ph3 LGS study succeeds; Epidiolex shows statistically significant
benefit on monthly drop seizures versus placebo (p=0.0135). The
phase 3 study recruited 171 patients, randomized 1:1 to 20mg/kg/day
Epidiolex or pbo as add-on to current anti-epileptic treatment. Patients
in the study appear to be fairly treatment-resistant on average, as
participants were taking approximately 3 anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) and
had previously failed/tried an average of 6 other AEDs. At baseline, the
median drop seizure frequency was 74. Treatment with Epidiolex showed
a 22% (44% Epidiolex vs 22% pbo) effect size that was statistically
significant (p=0.0135). Encouragingly, GW noted that the robustness of
the efficacy was also validated through secondary efficacy endpoints, one
of which "responder rate" is the primary measure for EMA.

BE

• Safety profile similar to Dravet study, with a similar adverse event
rate but a modestly higher serious adverse event (AE) rate. 86% of
Epidiolex patients experienced an adverse event compared to 69% on
pbo with the most common adverse events (occurring in greater than
10 percent of Epidiolex-treated patients) were: diarrhea, somnolence,
decreased appetite, pyrexia, and vomiting. Twenty patients on Epidiolex
experienced a serious AE (9 of which were deemed treatment related)
compared with 4 on placebo. Notably, GW noted that the types of AEs
observed were similar to that seen in the Dravet study, with no change to
Epidiolex's safety profile.

BE

• Commentary on clobazam drug-drug interaction encouraging.
As expected, GW did not offer detailed data on subgroup analyses.
However, regarding the Epidiolex/clobazam drug-drug interaction, GW
noted: (1) 50% of pts were on clobazam, & efficacy on/off clobazam
was "good" (2) some Epidiolex-treated LGS patients who were not on
clobazam became seizure free during the study and (3) more than half
of the 50% of patients who were not on clobazam had tried and failed
clobazam previously.

12:02 pm
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Disclosed data are impressive, but some skepticism likely to remain
until we see the full data set. The data released today reaffirm that Epidiolex
is an active antiepileptic drug, proving to be additive to patients already on
antiepileptic agents but not obtaining satisfactory seizure results. We do think
some skepticism will remain until the full details are disclosed at an upcoming
medical meeting and expected journal publication given that key secondary
endpoints, including a responder analysis, were not discussed. As a reminder,
this endpoint, which measures the percentage of patients having at least a 50%
reduction in seizures, is an important endpoint for ex-U.S. regulators and is
also an important metric to better understand commercial appeal. Some
physicians may require a 50% reduction in seizure frequency to maintain a
patient on the drug once it is approved. Publication of data from the first
Dravet Syndrome trial is expected in 4Q16, and additional data are likely to be
presented at the American Epilepsy Society (AES) annual meeting in December.

BE

(I've seen lots of criticism of GW's tendency to release incomplete data. But the criticism has mostly come from people known to be short, so I do nothing other than note it.)

12:03 pm
BE

Possible expedited regulatory pathway represents upside to base case
valuation. GWPH will meet with the FDA in summer 2016 for a pre-NDA
meeting to discuss the Phase 3 Epidiolex results in Dravet Syndrome and
potentially the pathway forward in LGS. Importantly, if the FDA agrees to allow
an NDA submission based on a single Dravet's trial, this would suggest the
agency is supportive of the existing data, thereby de-risking the entire
Epidiolex development program and potentially expediting the regulatory
pathway, in our view. We currently model NDA submission in 1H17, and
believe an expedited regulatory pathway represents upside to our base case
valuation.

BE

Outcome of this binary event closest to our Scenario 3, with some
remaining residual risk to the second LGS trial. We view the positive data
in this first LGS trial as incremental de-risking for the Epidiolex development
program, although the lack of details around some of the efficacy and safety
findings, as well as the high placebo rate, lead to remaining residual risk in the
second LGS trial. We are increasing our probability of success in LGS to 65%
from 60%, though we note this is less probability of success than we model for
Dravet Syndrome (75%). In our note event
we outlined 5 potential outcome scenarios. We believe
the LGS data are most similar to scenario 3 in that Epidiolex produced
statistically significant efficacy, though the delta vs. placebo is less than was
seen in the first Dravet study, leaving some remaining residual risk to the
second LGS trial. Based on the incremental de-risking from this trial, we are
increasing our PT to $152 from $149, remain OW.

BE

SO. Fingers crossed.
